Definition: Break down the given comment into Identity-attack and Non-identity-attack. Identity attack refers to anything offensive, rude about one’s identity.

Comment: "In order for a statement to be defamatory, it should tend to harm one’s reputation. That can mean that it makes others think less of person about whom the statement is made, or deters others from wanting to deal with that person, or tends to lower that person’s standing in the community. For a statement to be defamatory, it must assert a fact ... and the statement must be understood by a reasonable person to be an assertion of fact.

The requirement that the defamatory statement be published to a third party means that the statement must be spoken to someone other than the person about whom the statement is made, or must be written and delivered to some other than the person about whom the statement is made. This requirement is easily met where the defamatory statement is published in a newspaper, broadcast on television or the internet, or spoken to an audience."
( http://www.cohenlawdenver.com/civil-litigation/defamation/ )

Comment: One of the signal features of modern science communication is that when something new is being reported, a curious person can look around and see how it is being described across a spectrum of media. Will say in that regard that many other places are reporting a deep, deep skepticism with this finding. It isn't that it is "certain to spark debate" but it has generated almost simultaneously with publication lots of negative responses. See the New York Times' https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/01/science/earths-oldest-bacteria-fossils.html as an example. I don't know what the ultimate verdict on the finding will be but in my mind the "news" is that there is a big clash between what the paper purports to have found, and what people in the field think is actually there.

Comment: Alaska, like 37 other states that vote predictably in presidential elections, is politically irrelevant.  

Small state math means absolutely nothing to presidential campaign polling, organizing, ad spending, and visits, or to presidents once in office. 

In the 25 smallest states in 2008, the Democratic and Republican popular vote was almost tied (9.9 million versus 9.8 million), as was the electoral vote (57 versus 58). 

In 2012, 24 of the nation's 27 smallest states received no attention at all from presidential campaigns after the conventions. They were ignored despite their supposed numerical advantage in the Electoral College. In fact, the 8.6 million eligible voters in Ohio received more campaign ads and campaign visits from the major party campaigns than the 42 million eligible voters in those 27 smallest states combined.  

Voters in states, of all sizes, that are reliably red or blue don't matter.

Comment: Murkowski's complaint about ANWR becoming a monument has little to no connection with the residents of the islands wanting a sanctuary around their homes and requesting one. An ANWR monument would not violate ANILCA because ANILCA specifically exempted areas set aside prior to 1980. ANWR was set aside in 1960. Further, the 'no more clause' in ANILCA would not survive close examination by the courts, who have held since 1920 that large monuments are permitted, and that the size of the monument is the presidents call. Monuments in ANWR and Bristol Bay will be upheld, under Supreme Court precedent, and the fact AK has no standing to challenge any monuments in its borders , under Alaska vs Carter (1980). It is the courts, not Congress, that determine the legality of actions by the presidents, in the case of monuments, the courts have upheld every monument ever challenged, including all 17 of Carters. Likewise any monuments Obama creates will be upheld.

Comment: My understanding is that there are usually an "Alpha" male and female in most wolf packs.  The male, usually the strongest and most aggressive one, fights the other males for breeding rights, and the female is the leader.  If a rancher shoots either Alpha then the pack falls into a lower state of order, and breeding diminishes for a while.  When Fish and Feathers employees do the culling, or the public is given permits, there is usually no distinction made between the Alpha's and other wolves.  Were clear photos made (remotely activated Go Pro's) available, the Alpha's could be identified, and spared.  A good reason for sparing the Alphas is that wolves are intelligent enough to understand that hunting around certain areas almost always gets some of their pack killed, and the Alphas then display avoidance behavior.  A lot of the culling takes place in the deep woods, where the Alphas can't get any clue as to why they are being killed, nor where there may be "safe" areas.

Comment: "You may actually want to visit the CRA website, where there's lots of handy income tax data... broken down by province."

So, you think that because they aggregate the data for convenience in analysis, by province, that it's somehow collected by province? We all pay taxes individually, and you know it. Your employer withholds the recommended rate, and you top up or get a rebate if that recommended rate is too high. The provincial government, or any provincial body, has literally nothing to do with it. Each corporation pays its federal taxes, separately, too.

In fact, it is the FEDS that collect provincial income taxes on the province's behalf, and forward them their tax share at the end of the fiscal year, not the other way around.

Comment: "Was the customer backlash expected? Corpus paused. For 12 seconds. “No,” he finally said."

If this is true, then he's an idiot, pure and simple. He does not know his customer base at all.  And either he hasn't bothered to hire people who understand customer behavior, or he's too arrogant to listen to them.

Sure you can charge for storage. That's a given. Comment: The military is constrained by rules and regulations (and particularly the ones Clinton ignored about Classification) for which violation results in jail.  Military leadership is authoritarian, not democratic.  

"Voting on promotions" is funny!  There are actually 'promotion boards' made up of higher ranking individuals who actually do vote as to whether a senior NCO or Officer, based on his documented performance evaluations should be promoted early, with his peers or not at all.  And at the ranks of SSG and Major and above failure to be promoted with your peers means you released from active duty.  

And someone can't be promoted to an initial  General or Admiral rank or any higher such rank without Senate approval.

The military has adopted many of the civilian words' management tools for its leadership as well.  Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs is one of the beginning tools.  Leadership training is required to make Sergeant and each subsequent rank.  Same thing for Lieutenants etc.

Comment: I have driven BMW's for years and they are nice. However, my next car will not be a BMW.

I do not like the run flat tires. If one is punctured it must be replaced. Given the short range that you can drive after a puncture I would not want to experience a flat on the Icefields Parkway. A replacement would probably have to come from Calgary and take a day or more to arrive. BMW's do not carry spares.

All the high tech gizmos in this car do not improve the driving experience for me. From what I can tell they are just selling features. Based on my experience they also reduce fuel efficiency as they draw power from the engine.

Overall I think BMW's are over priced and over hyped for what you get.

Comment: I would like to commend the Anchorage police, paramedics, and fire department for the professionalism they show, and for their quick responses to crime and accidents in our city.
     I was behind the car that crossed the center line yesterday on Dowling, and could hear the screams and wailing from the car that took a head-on hit.  Like several others, I parked and jumped out of my car to see if I could help.  The police were there within two minutes.  The fire trucks and ambulances were also there in minutes.  Every one was kind, calm, and helpful.  CPR was performed even as one person was lifted into the ambulance.  Jaws of life was used to free one person from a car.  Everything was done to attend the victims.  
     I was also impressed with how many citizens ran to help, and then stayed with the teenaged girls and their mom until professionals took over.  A man named John stabilized the mom's neck and the words he spoke were comforting and appropriate.
     Amazing, kudos!

Comment: The one variable Samuelson and economists maybe overlooking is the number of folks who have dropped out and are dropping out of the workforce and is skewing that 4.3% unemployment figure.  In other words the number of workers available is declining but not the number of people who need to be housed, clothed, and fed.  Another variable that may be effecting this rosy unemployment number is the number of folks under-employed and/or holding multiple jobs to make ends meet.  I think the real numbers economists should be looking at as opposed to unemployment are the number of workers who have no savings, no/under insured (all types, not just medical), live pay check to pay check (if that), and the number in poverty (growing/declining).  But those numbers if bad, could rattle businesses/markets and send us into a recession or even a depression.  Maybe we don't want know?

Comment: Issues that affect 2 of the 3 NAFTA nations directly but affect the third hardly or not at all should be address by the 2 involved partners talking and their proposed solution then presented to the 3rd (which should only raise concerns that were overlooked earlier) and the solution then be added to the list of proposed NAFTA revisions.

However, it is not appropriate (nor in Canada's interests) for one but not both of the US's NAFTA partners to bilaterally negotiate with the US a change that will materially affect the 3rd partner and then present that 3rd partner with a fait accompli.  While it may be tempting to Canadian negotiators to be free of involvement in the negotiation of issues unique to the US-Mexico relationship (or even to gain favourable terms on other matters from the US by participating in a gang-up on Mexico), such abandonment of Mexico would tarnish our reputation and influence in Latin America and elsewhere and isolate us in future situations for a long time.

Comment: Well, I did my bit and was going to work until 67 but got laid off a year before that. There's already no retirement age in Ontario so there was nothing to prevent me from doing so.

What I find strange with this idea, however, is that we already have major problems where people are getting let go in the 40s and 50s and find it increasingly difficult to get a new job - how do you stop that? There are people ready, willing and able to work past 65 but not that many get the opportunity. The other big issue is that there are some somewhat reasonable arguments that new graduates are having a tough job joining the workforce, I know for sure that in the high tech business, new graduates can't get their foot in the door because companies all want very specific work experience. IMHO, it's even more of a priority to get more young people into the work force than to have older people work on. The latter simply takes the load of pension services and allows the employee to save up a bit more.

Comment: I agree that the framers of the Constitution were the elite.  They were the intellectual giants of their time, and some like Madison and Jefferson have no equal to this day.  But they were men of their time, Jefferson was a slave owner.  What they created, however, was not a government for the elite.  Every time I read the Preamble to the Constitution, I marvel at the vision and wisdom of the framers of the Constitution.  The Constitution was a compromise to satisfy the disparate demands of the 13 signatory states  It has been amended 27 times, but the Preamble has remained pristine, untouched.  American democracy was not still born.  It worked through its gestation period in Philadelphia and emerged to become the American Democracy.  We are not perfect, but I don't know of any other form of government I would rather have.  American Democracy is under siege from corruption today.  .That's the battle we have to win.  Call me a high school idealist; I will gladly accept that.

Comment: As so often in these threads, I find myself calling for more nuance. Partly because of the limited chatacters format.

Yes, there is a very close connection between the way the Eucharist is celebrated and the words and actions of Jesus at the Last Supper. I believe that very connection is represented by the three synoptic Gospel accounts plus Paul's, but that those accounts are already influenced by the way the community is celebrating the Eucharist.

So, for example, in your critical reading of Scripture you might notice that in the original Greek, Paul and Luke use the verb eucharistein, whereas Matthew and Mark used the verb eulogein. Anyone who wants to say the Gospel pericopes give us an exact account of Jesus' words has a problem explaining this difference.

The simple explanation is that these scripture texts are presenting the Last Supper in the terminology of how the community celebrated the Eucharist. There was unity in purpose and intent, but diversity of actual practice.

Comment: Thank heavens somebody is talking sense on the fragmented publicly funded schools.  It's high time that Bill Davis's folly to give funding to Catholic high schools was rolled back. To remove funding from Catholic elementary schools would be a bonus, despite the fact that it was enshrined in the British North America Act.  My son played rep basketball about fifteen years ago.  The out of town tournaments were held almost exclusively in Catholic high schools.  These were veritable palaces compared to his midtown public high school, which more resembled a gothic horror movie set than a learning institution, with its falling acoustic ceiling tiles, broken lockers and bathroom cubicles with missing doors. Why did this happen?  Because after 1985 so much money was siphoned out of the public school system to fund Catholic high schools and the parallel administration to the public high schools.  If Newfoundland can kick churches out of education, there is no reason Ontario can't!

Comment: In the 1970's a fisherman rescued a baby fur seal that was injured in his boat net and the mother was no where to be found. I kept the seal in my new bathroom. It ate herring from the sink and I kept the light on in the bathroom because he liked to sit on the closed toilet ad sun himself. The vet tended the baby seal's extensive cuts on it's skin at no charge. On day while cleaning the seal's cuts the vet did a nice "baby" to the seal while he lifted his hand up in front of the seal's face to pat it on the head. The seal quickly grabbed the vet's hand and inflicted a terrible bite to his right hand. The seal has a full set off teeth that look like sharp needles with no spaces in between. Patting a seal on the head is not a good idea. I kept the seal for 3 months and he liked to slide down my carpeted stars when the door bell rang and pushed the window curtain away to see who was at the door. Due to his  injuries he was not able to be released.  He went to live in the Seattle Aquarium.

Comment: Since Justin Trudeau has been in office for most of 2015Q4 it is reasonable to take the 2016Q3 update as a report card on how well he did in terms of growth in his first year in power. The annual growth rate (i.e. 2016Q3 as compared to 2015Q3) was 1.3%, i.e. less than the 1.7% annualized growth rate achieved by Harper (based on 2016Q3 as compared to 2005Q4). Calculated on a per capita basis, using the working age population, Trudeau achieved a growth rate of 0.3%, the same as Harper over his period in of office. . Expenditure-based  real GDP per capita is still not back to its level in 2014Q4 nor is industry-based real GDP per capita back to its level in December 2014. So as of September, Trudeau had still not taken us from a recovery back into an expansion, although the 2015H1 contraction ended in June 2015. This is truly pathetic for a leader who promised growth, growth, growth during the 2015 election. He has turned a budget surplus into a huge deficit with little to show for it.

Comment: " the desire to do something ... because it will bring him success, status or money."  With one exception (magazine cover--status?), the examples that follow could easily mean "do something creative," or "create something" aside from success, status or money. Other than create children, many never create much of any anything their entire lives.

The bucket list confirms that few want to feel that they're satisfied; they've experienced or achieved all they wanted, so...what's left, except death? As I left my 60s, I changed my attitude.  I once thought: well, when I go, I'll just wrap it up nice and neat.  No loose threads, half-finished projects, nothing left incomplete.  Nice and tidy.  Silly. 

Whenever it is I go, I want all KINDS of things left undone: books I haven't read, movies not seen, projects half-completed.  See?  No boredom.  No ennui, and something else--the ABILITY to keep experiencing right to the end., and so, too busy right to the end, to make a list.

University of Alaska ($891 million)

Comment: An interesting thesis that would likely do a better job of describing modern political thought than the traditional binary definitions.

However, it's not all that radical or new.  The left right divide was never a comprehensive analysis of individual, or even party, views.  It was merely a convenient way to generalize complex attitudes on a variety of issues.

If we were to assign the 8 labels Preston has outlined, you can bet that it would expand at an incredibly rapid rate as people nitpick over the nuances of each.  As an example, Facebook now offers 58 gender identities:

http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/headlines/2014/02/heres-a-list-of-58-gender-options-for-facebook-users/

Do we really want politics to become even more baffling and divisive by making the identity of such more confusing?

Comment: This article misses the point by miles and miles.   Are there problems with single payer, sure but if you have no access to healthcare or will go bankrupt trying to get care 9 months to wait is not a long time.  I am an American who lives in London and has done so for 8 years.   Please stop acting like the US insurance run medical industry is superior to gov't funded medical care.  It is not!!  For one thing, ironically, having to stay in a job you hate just o keep access to health care as many Americans do, is not freedom but the opposite.  In the UK, you have the NHS (tax funded) and private care (individual or work funded) but everyone, and I mean everyone, has access.  What is the issue with that?  Is it that the author thinks some Americans don't deserve access to HC?  I am a LTC in the Army and guess what the Army has,  tax payer healthcare and no one seems to be bothered by that.  America has the wealth and innovation to give everyone healthcare, stop acting like we can't!

Comment: Canada is not Australia - different legal considerations.  Australia is like Canada was prior to April 17, 1982 when the constitution was patriated and we rejected the principle of parliamentary supremacy

Unlike Australia Canada, has a constitutionally entrenched Charter of Rights that is part of the supreme law of the land.  As we saw in the 1985 SCOC decision Singh v Canada (Minister of Employment and Immigration), [1985] 1 S.C.R. 177 refugees within Canada are entitled to have their claim to refigee status adjudicated as matter of fundamental justice (our version of due process).

The Safe Third Country Agreement applies only to refugee claimants coming from the US and appearing at a Port Of Entry and it only works because the claimants have not yet entered Canada.  Once they are in the Charter is engaged and enforcement action for illegal entry is deferred until such time as it is determined if they are in fact Convention Refugees per s. 133 of the IRPA

Comment: When I went to the site listed it showed an average electricity price for the US for 2016 of 13.5 cents/kWh.  The data is from the US Department of Labor. Ontario Hydro shows a blended average for Ontario of 11 cents/kWh reflecting time of use usage. If you do not have a Smart Meter the average price is 10.3 cents/kWh for the first 1000 kWh. If you do have a Smart meter the cost varies from 8.7 to 18 cents/kWh. According to the Ontario Energy Board the average household uses 2/3 of their electricity during off-peak hours.  For San Francisco the 2016 average cost is 19.5 cents/kWh. What is not shown in either case are distribution costs and other administrative costs.

So electricity prices are not so low in the US they are higher than in Ontario.

Gasoline is another story. In Toronto we currently pay  about $1.09/L which is $4.12/gallon.  The US average for 2016 is $2.20/gallon. This is from the same data source. So gasoline prices are much lower in the US than in Canada.

Comment: I am a very senior sales professional. 17 years in large multinational firms. I have moved over $1B in volume in the last 10 years. Yes - a billion of top line revenue to my 2 employers in 10 years. I know exactly what I am worth. I get headhunted all the time. Typically the calls starts with the name of the firm (and it is usually a firm I would not want to work for). They tell me the role and territory, which is usually very large. They will not guarantee any commissions to make me want to walk away from my current role. If someone tried that 24 hour gimmick on me I would laugh at them and hang up.
I will tell the headhunter what I make. why? To manage expectations. If they sigh or whistle at hearing that number I know they are not for real. Good headhunters know what top guys like me make. Hearing my number does not phase them.  The reality is that if a good role at a good firm opens up in my region I know about it before the phone rings, and I am prepared when the call comes.

Comment: Currently no earthquake monitoring devices are in place at Ship Creek valley, except one at the Hilton Hotel. So real information about the ground motions characteristics is not exactly known in this part of the Anchorage Bowl. But based on my research on ground motions behavior in Anchorage basin and my understanding about the geological deposition of Ship Creek Valley, I can definitely conclude that the area is prone to high ground amplification during any earthquake in the Anchorage area. Whether to build  or not to build in this area, I will not argue on that, as it is policy of the city, I can only say based on scientific study that this area will show high ground amplification even at 5 Hz which is roughly the natural frequency of two storied building. So there will be a risk but how to offset that risk is surely a challenge for engineers.

Comment: The VA, DOD and all federal government employees all need to be on the same travel regulation.  Currently one pays x while the other pays y for the same z.  One wants this, while the other wants that, and another doesn't want anything at all.

The Va currently pays veterans 1/2 the amount a VA employee would receive for the same location.  I guess vets only need half as much to eat or half as much room to sleep? 

Government travel regulations for the US require a myriad of ways of documentation using multiple pay charts.  I'm not talking about different areas but the same location.

For example, mileage between Fairbanks and Anchorage is  paid $5 more for coming back than going down.  Either the VA is overpaying for coming back or they are underpaying for going down.  Which is it?

The VA pays 41.5 cents per mile.  Military retirees under 65 get .7 cents per mile and active duty gets 53.5 cents per mile.  Same road, different systems.

Uniformity would save time and money.

Comment: Scott:  You mention "current" abuse.  Would you be good enough to expand on your contention.  I presume you're referencing a possible initiative which might lead to a further initiativve to control aerial spraying of herbicides.  If, indeed, that is your concern, fine, you should be addressing that particular issue, not supporting an "end run" effort which would give the Board veto power over all initiatives which Lane County voters have worked hard to, and have in fact, qualified for the ballot.  May I again state: The initiative process comes with "built-in" checks to "weed out" frivolous measures.  First, it requires a significant number of petition signatures to qualify for the ballot.  Secondly, it requires a majority of voters to support its adoption. Thirdly, it,like all ordinances, would be subject to judicial review.  At each step proponents must make a convincing argument that the measure is a) constitutional and b) desirable.  This process is called DEMOCRACY.

Comment: PERS tier I was primarily boosted by a Republican Governor (Vic Atiyah) and a Republican legislature.   This was in place of  cost of living adjustments when inflation was running on the order of magnitude of 10%/a.   At that time 8%/a  was minimal.  A conservative deposit account could get 15%/a--(still have a long term bond with that yield!).  Attributions of >20%/a in the '90's by the PERS board were rolled back by the courts.  The board voted such high returns in an effort to match investment market run-ups in the dot com era,  just to prevent runs on PERS by members making early withdrawals.   Who knew that 0%/a on treasuries would be the new normal?

Comment: “But this case demonstrates that, like democracy itself, our complex system of governance is better than its alternatives.”
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Unfortunately, Donald Trump isn’t aware that he lives in a democracy. In addition to the three branches of government (Legislative, Executive, Judicial) healthy democracies depend on free elections, opposition parties and a free press. And yet, Trump belittles “so-called judges”, he says elections are “rigged”; he calls his opponents “liars” and “crooks”; and the media, according to him, are biased and dishonest.

Unlike his businesses, President Trump is not running an empire, he is governing a country. He is responsible to the people – they employ him --  and he is bound by a Constitution and the laws which arise from it. Unless he learns very quickly the meaning of “democracy” his days as president are numbered.

Comment: Voter fraud is not the same as System fraud.  WA state can only find 74 possible -- as yet unproven -- cases of fraud to investigate.  That isn't widespread fraud, even if all 74 cases are prosecuted.  I hope the Herald will follow up with the alleged frauds.

Most states haven't examined their systems forensically.  Those same states also refused the offer by our government to help them use advanced forensics to examine their systems.  They cite states rights (to do nothing).

Outdated machines, without a printout that can be verified by the voter, are easily hacked or tampered with (and there are a lot of them still in use).  Ballot counters can be tampered with.  All election software can be tampered with.  All of it should be examined and/or replaced with secure systems.

Voter fraud being covered up?  Yawn.  Voter fraud being over-hyped as widespread?  Yep.

Comment: But unlike Pakistan, Canada is an advanced, progressive society where men and women are treated as equals and we don't subjugate women under the guise of piety or modesty. This is not about cultural relativism or "diversity", it is a function of progress. Canada isn't Tehran or Peshawar or Riyadh, not because we are different, because we are an advanced secular society. The niqab is part of a belief system that kills homosexuals and censors any critical analysis of religion under penalty of death. Comment: I have a very simple ETF portfolio, based on slightly older funds that split US, Global and Emerging markets into 3 funds because the All-World Ex-Canada funds were not available when I designed my current portfolio. Plus a 5-year GIC ladder. And a low-cost global equity mutual fund for my mad money. And another low-cost balanced mutual fund to keep cash distributions invested. So even the simplest portfolio can have slight complexities.

I used to consider adding REITs, short-term or high-yield bonds, or preferred shares. Or dividend stocks. A lot of segment ETFs have much higher MERs. Every time I think about it I realize that a lot of those holdings would concentrate my portfolio, not diversify it, while adding costs that might never be overcome by any performance gains. So simple wins for me, to a point.

Comment: One aspect of the NAFTA agreement that Canada, the US and Mexico could usefully revisit is the provision that allows private corporations from country A doing business (or wanting to do so) in country B to challenge before an independent tribunal the laws and administrative practices of general application in country B on the grounds that they somehow place the company doing business in country B at a disadvantage compared to companies from country B.  

The rulings of such tribunals have been unpredictable and arguably overreaching.  These negotiations are an opportunity to prune back and refine the provision in question.  Doing so would also smooth the way for Canada in its ongoing negotiations with Pacific rim countries and the EU regarding free trade deals.

Comment: I am relating to you my experience in an ancient Religious Order in both the UK and in Rome. 
In the U.K. we could go into the local village at the weekend to confess to the local parish priest if we wanted to. We could also confess to a priest of the community if we so wished. There was absolutely no compulsion whatsoever to be 'herded into the confessional'.
In college in Rome the practice was exactly the same, we clerics were able to go to Confession wherever and whenever we liked. Never in all the time that I was a postulant, novice or under vows was any pressure put upon me to go to Confession, either in my home country or in the heart of Christendom, Rome.
First of all the provincial superiors of Religious Orders would be based in a single location and therefore unable to sit at the back of every house under their jurisdiction. Another thing is that religious superiors were never referred to as 'vicars' so I wonder if you know what you are talking about.

Comment: As long as the people don't have to pay for yet another legislative  legal fishing expedition (like we did for the Medicaid expansion lawsuit folly) than let the good Senator proceed.   However, how can he not call the permanent fund expenditure an appropriation subject to veto?  The State Constitution (Article 9, Section 16) clearly  states that the "appropriation"  for the Alaska Permanent Fund payments is not limited as are other appropriations.  That seems to indicate that the permanent fund is indeed an "appropriation" regardless of the amount  to be appropriated.  That same Constitution (Article 2 Section 15)  states that the Governor may: "....by veto strike or reduce items in appropriation bills".   
Remember, we are about to spend another $800,000 for a study  on how we can become more  efficient with  state spending.  I wonder if legislative lawsuits against the the state government will be looked at?

Comment: I graduated college thirty years ago with a degree in broadcast journalism. I could not tell you the first or last name a single professor in the department I received my degree in. I can tell you the first and last names of exactly three professors, as well as quite a bit about them. Two were political science professors, the first a Democrat and the second a self-proclaimed anarchist. The other was an anthropology professor who was a strongly opinionated Republican. They were the three most influential professors of my college career in no small part because they had no qualms about encouraging debate in their classrooms and were very skilled at deconstructing the views of their students and forcing them to think more thoroughly. Had they been required to "stick to the material" those classes would have failed to stimulate my lifelong love of learning and I would be an intellectually poorer person for it. Their classes were not safe zones. That's why their classes were so good.

Comment: Terrorism is an important issue. However, given that there are so few people actually killed and it is so rare, aren't there more pressing issues and risks to discuss?

What about Syria? It looks as though ISIS is on the run. What will a post ISIS Syria look like? What role should NATO and the G7 play, if anything?

What about the DPNK? Within the next few years the DPNK is expected to have a ICBM and miniaturized nuclear warhead (i.e. inside of Trump's first term). When India and Pakistan got nuclear weapons no one worried because they were not a direct threat to anyone but themselves. This is different. Kim has boasted he wants to use these weapons to get what he wants. This is unacceptable. What if anything should NATO and the G7 do?

What about Russia / Ukraine? China? World trade? Cyber Security?, etc.

I suspect talking about terrorism is a way to focus President Trump on a topic most can agree on vs. anything that requires thought and debate. Sad.

Comment: E:  If, as you say, you want everyone to pay then only a sales tax or some use of the PF will meet that criteria.  A state personal income tax is based on the amount of federal income tax an individual pays. Nearly 50% of wage earners do not pay a federal income tax.  Since that is true it is safe to assume that nearly 50% of Alaskan wage earners would not pay a state income tax.  That is one of the reasons a sales tax, if you must have a tax, is more fair.  That way EVERYONE, residents and non-residents, wage earners and non-wage earners who spend money in Alaska would pay a share for the state services and benefits they are provided.  Another reason is that a state sales tax is estimated to generate at least twice the amount of a personal income tax.

Comment: Outcomes for wealthy and well insured Americans are superior to those in Canada. There is no question that American medical research and infrastructure is vastly superior to what we have in Canada. The issue in the USA is that such expertise and infrastructure is not available to a large percentage of their population. Even among many of those Americans that are insured, they get 'basic' coverage, not the 'premium' levels of healthcare available to wealthy Americans.

The averaging of outcomes for key metrics such as life expectancy, infant mortality, etc. reflects a large population of uninsured and under-insured Americans relative to a more broadly based coverage in Canada.

That being said, both US and Canadian healthcare systems suck big time when compared to most European countries and others like Japan, Australia and New Zealand.

Comment: If private lenders want to accept all the risk of lending "down payment" money to would-be homebuyers, fine, good for them if they can take the risk.  As long as they remain last to be paid (from the proceeds of a forced sale) when things get ugly, and the CMHC gets paid first, I have no issue with this.

The big issue that REMAINS is the overhang of insured mortgage debt for which taxpayers are ALREADY on the hook.  That (roughly) $800 billion exposure is taxpayers to keep, and all we can do is stop digging the hole ever deeper. 

Let's see a much lower limit on the size of mortgage that can be insured ($400k or less), as an interim step towards scrapping government-backed insurance altogether. Raise the premiums.  We might also consider further taxes or limits on foreign buyers, scrapping dual citizenship, etc...  But you can't pin crazy prices in small/mid size cities on the outside buyers - that is mostly longtime citizens overpaying with CMHC-backed loans.

With discretionary voting where the unused votes are left to the board discretion, homeless and lost shareholders are used by management to control the shareholders and the stock.
The solution is ANCSA election reform. One person one vote, no proxies.

Comment: Matthew, water vapor is a feedback not a forcing. Realclimate can help you with the distinction between the two. 

http://www.realclimate.org/index.php/archives/2005/04/water-vapour-feedback-or-forcing/

It's residence time in the atmosphere is on the order of ~10 days whereas CO2's residence time is on the order of 100's to 1000's of years. Or to put it bluntly, the energy from water vapor long wave absorption is staying practically the same, while the energy from CO2 long wave absorption is only going up. 

BTW, the wavelength of a typical photon traverses ~330 CO2 molecules. On average a photon at the surface will travel a couple of meters before it is absorbed. Go ahead argue with the Physical Chemists. 

http://rabett.blogspot.com/2016/04/its-number-density-not-mixing-ratio.html

Comment: Neither of those were in the USSR now were they ?
> even if the USSR achieved some measure of gender equality: was it worth the cost?
No... but I certainly never suggested it was. I just think that rationality requires honesty about the facts, to reflexively act as if the USSR had no positive achievements whatsoever and never could have - is to be irrational as they most certainly DID have some, pioneering space travel was another, the AK-47 yet another, whats more, it denies us the opportunity to learn from their successes. Why should we ONLY learn from their failures ? 
In the same vein - if one is proposing a better system than capitalism - it would be disingenuous to pretend nothing good came out of it, even if (like me) you feel the amount of terrible outcomes are not at all worth the cost.
I would want to replicate the good things that came from it, while avoiding the bad things.

Currently the social democracies appear to have come the closest to doing so.

Comment: I see this move by our mostly Republican Lane County Board of Commissioners to increase purchase age of tobacco as one of their rare visionary actions.

It's an indicator of a growing concern and reaction over the social legitimacy and cost of tobacco, particularly after the corporate cigarette manufactures enhance the addictive properties by adding many extra chemicals. The message that further restrictions on tobacco sends is long over due, even if it limits the rights of teenagers.

Tobacco products are, by far, the most lethal and destructive drug in America, yet they aren't even on the federal controlled substance list. It's an unfair bow to one of the most powerful and twisted political influences in our country.

Reading about the costs to our collective health and medical care at https://www.cdc.gov/tobacco/data_statistics/fact_sheets/fast_facts/, I'm even more impressed with this shot across big tobacco's bow. Go commissioners, raise the age right away!

Comment: In 2002 then house rep Shawn Mitchell drafted the Asset Forfeiture Reform Act which did pass. Among other limitations on law enforcement one was very simple. This law demand that there MUST BE A CONVICTION before assets can be seized. This is Colorado law.
Showing all the respect that some LEOs have for law, they hired attorneys to find loopholes and then continued to seize assets before a conviction. The perpetrators of this conspiracy to defraud citizens not convicted, are the police and state prosecutors. The legislature is attempting to close some of these loopholes and get the cops to follow the law (not find ways around it). 
The ones who protest the loudest should be the most suspect.

Comment: There have been a number of discussions about the percentage of GET paid by visitors with calculations of about 14% up to 33% or so.  Even if the visitor portion is 33%, that leaves $5.6 billion (out of $10 billion) to be paid by residents.   That’s a heck of a lot of money.  

Real property taxes are recognized as less regressive than the GET.

Comment: No, it just proves that market forces aren't quite what you want them to be.  You want them to use a single assumption (that consumers have no up-front budgets, that they'll stay in their home for the life of the bulb, that they shouldn't care about a bulb's other shortcomings, etc).  But that's the beauty of the market -- it's not for one person to decide what's of value, it's each consumer individually making that choice based on the criteria that matters to them.

And just because SOME bulbs (typically the more expensive ones) had better features sooner than others doesn't mean the ALL did.  Or that even MOST did.  Most people can't/won't pay premium prices when there's "good enough" available at much cheaper prices.

Comment: I would say the public in fact pays well over 50% of the cost of civil service pensions, when you consider that the same job in the public sector now pays markedly more than on the private side.  So, the government pays, say, an $80,000 salary, plus the employer's pension payment (Say $10,000).  Then the employee pays $10,000, it is true, but that comes out of pretax income, since this is a Registered Pension Plan.  But a private worker can use an RRSP to the same effect, so that is not a real difference - the difference is that the government worker is probably paid at least $10,000 more, and probably $20,000, in the first place. Taxpayers fund that overpayment.  If that is true then, indeed, the pension can be thought of as entirely paid for by the taxpayers.  
The larger point is that in assessing the fairness of public sector pay, including within education, health, ministries, and so on, you need to count all pay, benefits, perks, and the likely value of the DB pensions.

2.  There are too-many "right-on-green-only lights.  Because of these, people sit at controlled intersections twice as long.  Many times, cars are waiting to turn left, and there isn't a car in sight approaching.
3.  They should turn off many of the traffic lights during non-rush-hour times.
4.  Ditto for the left turn arrows.  Aurora has wised up, and has some of these just flash yellow unless a red arrow is needed.
5.  Few lights even need to be on after 8:00 PM.  But yet, we sit.
When people are in their cars, they want to DRIVE, not sit at intersections.  These are over controlled, in my opinion.  When people know they will be sitting, they rush to beat the light.  Eventually, they just run the red.

Comment: Here's my ideas, though I'm no economist or financial guru, these are things that stick in my craw.

Eliminate the School Boards, or at the least, allow school vouchers for about 75% of the current amount spent on students.  Competition is always a healthy thing.

Oil taxes are beyond my level of comprehension.  Simplify them to: Flat Taxing the oil pulled from the ground.  Period.  No deductions, no incentive pay.  Feel free to drill, and we'll tax what goes in the pipeline or onto a tanker, whatever.

Taxes:  that's a tough one.  Sales or income?  If we go with sales, that means everyone, rich and poor alike, will have a stake in the state's well being.  Bad side of that is it places an extra burden on townsfolk that already have a sales tax, like Wasilla, Seward.

Income tax: Make it a flat tax.  I don't like punishing someone for being more successful than I.  Plus, you can deduct state income from your federal taxes.  That can come in handy!

There you have it.  Discuss.

Comment: I am always amazed by the number of BC Public School Teachers who, like NDP MLA Moe Sihota, send their kids to Private School. Sihota's Daughter was funded by a family friend, but the teachers who do this do it on their own dime. Says a lot about their pay levels and about the standards in Public versus Private Schools, doesn't it? A BC math teacher friend volunteered for the Accreditation Review at another BC Public School. He wanted to note that the math achievement was sub par, and that whenever they had a school assembly they cancelled the math classes, going below the prescribed hours of math instruction. There was no way for him to record either observation in the review. It was set up to give a fixed, no problem here, move along result.

OTOH, someone we knew at a Private School viewed the process as life or death for their workplace. 

Also http://www2.gov.bc.ca/assets/gov/education/administration/kindergarten-to-grade-12/reports-and-publications/2010_factfinder_report_bcct.pdf

Comment: The owner's manual to my trusty old Land Rover Disco II strongly discouraged boosting another car or having the car jump started by anyone other than a Land Rover tech based on the "fried electronics" argument. The manual for a friend's Volvo has similar cautionary verbiage. For the most part, giving a boost is easy - but take it slow and make sure the order is correct. The instructions that come with the cables are worth keeping as a reminder.  I haven't had to ask for or offer battery assistance to a fellow motorists for years!  Keep your car tuned - go to CAA free winterizing clinics where the battery is tested... and occasionally pop the hood and look at the guts of your car. Really dirty, corroded or oily... time for a trip to the mechanic for a tune up service. All part of being a responsible adult... that and offering assistance where you feel comfortable and safe doing so.

Comment: Legal marijuana only simply needs to be (a) easy to obtain and (b) reasonably priced, to squish aside illegally produced marijuana.

Producing marijuana is not like producing alcoholic spirits, wine or beer.  It requires very little specialized equipment, it largely looks after itself, and once it's harvested and dried it's ready to use.

The government will need to absolutely forget their cash cow model that they are using with alcohol and tobacco and associated sin taxes.  Just charge GST/PST and an additional 5% marijuana tax.  Dont be greedy.

A pack of cigarettes in BC costs over $10.  Yet it costs $2.50 to produce, $3.00 to get it into your hands.  The other $7+ is going to the government.  What is the result?  Copycat counterfeit cigarettes from China and $20 cartons bought off native reserves, smuggling.

Enough with the social engineering using taxation, for god sakes.  Let people make up their own minds when it comes to what they put in their bodies.

Comment: If you work for the Legislature you are exempt from the State Personnel Act and you're pretty close to an "at will" employee; the Legislature can dismiss you for any reason, no reason, but not for an illegal reason.   Being rude in the estimation of a Legislator is not an illegal reason.   Distributing political material is not an illegal reason.   Making a profane comment about a Senator is not an illegal reason and will likely get you fired no matter which party is involved.

I did labor relations for the State for almost thirty years; I can count on my fingers the employees below the appointee level who've been fired for political activities, though lots should have been.   They've been hauled in, questioned, maybe intimidated, at least if I did it they were, but few got fired and it was always egregious conduct.   Go read some court cases; the State doesn't lose these cases other than a couple of dumba** cases in Jack Coghill's "dot chart" campaign back in Hickel.

Comment: I grew up in Michigan.  We could not swim in rivers or lakes due to industrial pollution (which since has been ended and one CAN swim today).  We passed a simple law which helped a great deal.  Industry must put put water in upstream of where they take it out.  The water must be more pure than when they took it. And NO storage of toxic material is permitted in any place where it could be leached by groundwater, because ground water eventually ends up in the Great Lakes (which are thought to be the largest freshwater reserve in the world).  My problem with these new Alaska mine projects is that they do not actually plan to deal with toxins properly (no doubt due to cost).  It is only worth mining IF you can afford to secure or clean up the mess as part of the deal, IMHO.  I favor development, if but only if you include full cleanup in the plan.

Comment: That's a common misconception about tenured faculty. It depends on the department, college or university. Some tenured faculty are expected to publish a lot, whereas others are not expected to publish at all. I know of full professors who haven't published in a decade but have earned "honors" and "awards" and pay increases not contingent on publishing. Some are rewarded for other activities, or simply by the reputation they earned many years ago. Sometimes, like in any organization, there is favoritism, nepotism, etc.

The status of tenure is also changing with this new generation of faculty, as universities and colleges no longer have (and most can't financially sustain) as many tenured faculty as they once did. This coincides with the fact that the structure of higher education is also changing as online education is becoming more prominent and campus-based higher education is less necessary for delivering quality research and instruction to a wide audience anywhere.

Comment: Here's the potential downside to Rob's advice, when someone lacking in knowledge chooses to go from an advisor to DB. Disclosure: I am an advisor and used to work at a major bank, so I'm speaking from second hand experience.

I'm not saying investing is super-hard and every investor needs people like me to do it, but here's what I saw a lot of when I was at the bank: people investing in regular commission-based, even back end loaded funds in DB accounts. Back in the day these were my prospects and my proposal to them was simply: "you're already paying the commissions... pay nothing extra and get a financial plan from me". 

That's where I see the investor in Rob's article going: moving it all to the bank's DB, keeping most of the same funds... bank's DB reaps all the trailing commissions without having to pay an advisor.

The investor's first move should be to start interviewing some other advisors, who aren't "fast-talkers".

Comment: mahalo Kristen for your mana'o. Please allow me to offer mana'o from the Hawaiian perspective.

Your story fails to take into account one critically important fact. That is that the Kingdom of Hawai'i has been a neutral nation since 1843. This means that, under international law, the presence of a foreign military force, like that of the US, in the neutral Kingdom of Hawai'i constitutes a serious war crime.

Some argue that Hawai'i was legally annexed by the US in 1897 after it backed a coup d'etat orchestrated by the 13 traitors of the white supremacist Committee of Safety. However the ratification of the Hawai'i Annexation Treaty of 1897 was rejected by the US congress on the grounds that the annexation of a Hawai'i by the US was illegal especially since a majority of Hawai'i's citizens signed petitions against annexation.

The US has failed to produce any evidence of the legal annexation of Hawai'i and, when challenged on the question of the legality of its claim, it remains silent.

Comment: "...2015, when the exchange rate was still ok"

Right there you show you don't know anything. The exchange rate being "OK" ie. the 1 CAD was closer to 1 USD would not be an advantage to a physician returning to Canada. It would be a disadvantage.

With the Canadian dollar lower now it is more to the advantage of someone in the US selling their assets - home etc. - and moving to Canada. Those US assets are worth more compared to the Canadian equivalent now that the dollar has fallen. Income from US investments are worth more now when converted to Canadian dollars than if the Canadian $ was closer to par.

Similarly, selling your Canadian house, etc. and taking those Canadian dollars to the US costs you more now. Now that the CAD has fallen moving to the US is a more expensive proposition. And once you're there with both your income and expenses in US$ it no longer matters one way or the other what the exchange rate is.

Comment: Taking your CPP early is financially always the right thing to do..unless you plan on travelling in your late 80's.  I took mine when I turned 60. Comment: Having driven from Toronto to Florida and back three times in electric cars I can assure you that this is not an issue. Comment: When you live in the patch, bad water and bad air​ is a fact of life. Above any commercially viable hydrocarbon reservoir are shallower ones that gradually leak out. In the Permian basin, for example, there are water wells that were drilled over 100 years ago, before any oil well had been drilled in Texas, and the water had enough methane in it to be flammable.

The town of Sweetwater, Texas got its name from being the 1st good water found near the Permian basin.

Comment: I have been to McNeill River twice and Brooks Camp twice.  I think a better balance to accommodate visitors is called for at McNeill River.  The staff, both times, were dogmatic and rigid.  I went the first time, in 1996, as a stand-by and went up to the falls on 2 of the 4 days.  That was enough.  Four days of sitting quietly in sometimes cold and rainy weather, can be pretty miserable.  To then go back to a tent is also pretty uncomfortable as well.

The only people that can afford this are trust fund babies and older individuals with sufficient monetary resources and there is a limited pool that want to participate given the restrictions.

ADF&G or the McNeill trust could build small cabins which would improve the visitor experience.  They have cabins for staff in remote areas all over the state.  At least when I was there getting fuel oil for cooking was a real pain.  It would be nice to furnish propane.

More in the next post.

Time to revive the earlier idea of per article micropayments.

Comment: Ontario has the most resources to its disposal to introduce a universal childcare program like Quebec. If Ontario stopped funding Catholic schools and transitioned to a 2 school public system for English and French - it could net upwards of $1B+ in savings on administrative and staffing costs. That $1B+ combined with existing childcare funding can be reinvested into a universal childcare program for children ages 1-5 (before they hit JK) with a sliding scale where the poorest pay almost nothing while the rich and middle class pay fair fees. Excess school buildings as a result of school mergers could be converted into public child care centers where necessary and others can be sold off to developers to be rezoned into new residential housing (another urgent Ontario need). How can Ontario cry poor when it comes to childcare funding when the Taxpayer is already funding a redundant public education system? Childcare should be classified as an education program not a social program !!!
